nl.quintor.solitaire.game.moves

Interface Move

  • All Known Subinterfaces:
    RevertibleMove
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    Quit

    public interface Move
    Interface representing a game move. A game move is defined as an action that can be taken by the player, which may or may not influence the GameState.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      java.lang.String apply(GameState gameState)
      Apply this move (to the GameState).
      Move createInstance(java.lang.String playerInput)
      Factory method to create a new instance of the implementing class.
      java.lang.String toString()
      The name of the implementing class to show to the player.

    • Method Detail

      • apply

        java.lang.String apply(GameState gameState)
                throws MoveException
        Apply this move (to the GameState). A MoveException is thrown if the move cannot be applied. The reason will be supplied in the message. The return value String can be shown to the player by the UI as a message. Likewise, the MoveException message can be shown as an error message.
        Parameters:
        gameState - GameState object to which this move will be applied
        Returns:
        message with the result of applying this move
        Throws:
        MoveException - on illegal move or error during move application

      • createInstance

        Move createInstance(java.lang.String playerInput)
        Factory method to create a new instance of the implementing class. The new Move object can use the player input as it wishes.
        Parameters:
        playerInput - the input of the player when requesting the action that this Move represents
        Returns:
        new instance of the class that implements the Move interface

      • toString

        java.lang.String toString()
        The name of the implementing class to show to the player. Override of Object method to force implementing classes to implement the method.
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        name of the implementing class, to identify the class to the player
